reviewText: OK, so Dre and Snoop were mismatched characters in this movie. I thought that only made for more laughs, myself. Snoop plays a thug type who earns the respect of everyone at the car wash where Dre goes for a job as well. Dre gets the job alright-as Snoop's boss! It starts out alright between them, but the job starts to go to Dre's head a bit and Dre starts losing respect from everyone working at the car wash, including Snoop. I think anyone who's a fan of Snoop and Dre will like this movie. The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because there is a very gross and unnecessary part in the movie where Dre buys a burrito off a vending truck, which Dre's boss warned him not to do. Well, Dre gets sick ...and it's shared with us. On the DVD, you may want to jump to the next scene if you have a weak stomach. Other than that, check it out.
summary: Good humor from Dre and Snoop

reviewText: Written and directed by DJ Pooh - who also plays Slim - the comedy features Dr. Dre (Sean) and Snoop Dogg (Dee Loc) as friends who have had bad breaks and made some poor choices, but stumble upon one last opportunity to get things together under some very bizarre circumstances.The cast is heavy into hip-hop, with Xzibit, Eminem, Kurupt and Truth Hurts having parts big & small. Other actors include Pauly Shore, Tommy Chong, Shaq and George Wallace (as car wash owner, Mr. Washington).The action mostly takes place at a car wash in Los Angeles, with Dr. Dre & Snoop Dogg being a surprisingly good comedic duo. And Eminem - as the fired assistant manager with major issues - is hilarious in his brief appearance.It is a wacky plot with over-the-top scenes and actors who are obviously having a blast. The editing sometimes makes following the plot a bit choppy, but that criticism can be directed at many comedies. The Wash is good for a few laughs and does not take things too seriously.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of those movies that was pushing 2 1/2 stars. I gave it a higher rating for two reasons: because most of the females in the movie looked hot, and I some how managed to laugh throughout most of the movie. This isn't a bad movie overall, but it does have some bad parts. It wasn't the best acting ever, but it was okay in this movie. Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg do an excellent job playing their parts and the plot execution is okay as well. Then you have a lot of popular west coast rappers in this movie as well aside from Dre and Snoop that many will easily recognize (I'm suprised Ice Cube didn't get mixed up in this). If you want to see a a few rappers and some nice females in a laughable movie, then check this out. It's not the best movie out there, but it isn't the worst. This is one of those movies that will be on TBS in about 2 years. Peace!
summary: Not That Bad At All (Rating: 7 out of 10- -3.5 stars)
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Friday" co-writer DJ Pooh tries for another run at the urban buddy comedy concept with superstar rap duo, Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg playing roomates who go from the closest of buds to being at odds when Dre gets a supervising job at the car wash where Snoop works. Despite a pretty solid supporting cast including George Wallace, Tommy "Tiny" Lister, Lamont Bentley, and Alex Thomas, this one is all over the place. Dre and Snoop's musical chemistry doesn't seem to translate too well into the cinematic world. Both seemed more comfortable in the bit parts they played in "Training Day" than they do trying to be the stars of their own feature. Pooh the writer seems content with sticking to the same tired drug humor and fart jokes while Pooh the director uses big-name rapper cameos to cover up these faults. The film is so stuffed with silly gags in fact that the movie's biggest conflict is pushed to the closing 20 minutes, leaving the audience with the impression that it probably isn't that important. "The Wash" has a few fleeting moments of humor including Kurupt as a neighborhood punk who interrogates Dre at gunpoint, Pooh as one of the bumbling kidnappers, and Eminem as a disgruntled former employee of the car wash. In the end though, it feels more like an R-rated episode of "Keenen & Kel" than a comedic gem like "Friday". While I was probably anticipating this movie more than anyone, it makes for a better rental than a purchase.

reviewText: With a script that didn't need any following and a plot that doesn't kick in until 20 minutes before the end, 'The Wash' is certainly no Oscar winner for acting or screenplay, but is a playful comedy about two friends, Dre's 'Sean' and Snoop's 'Dee Loc' trying to get by and pay the rent - but having fun along the way as well and, thinking about it, working what seems to be a very easy job at a garage.Dre is better suited to the straight man role whereas Snoop's pot dealing is laid out perfectly for him, 'The Wash' is simply a film that is basically a showcase of rappers fooling around and getting the chance to appear in a film - with cameos from Xzibit, Shaq O'Neill, Truth Hurts and an un-credited Eminem - who surprisingly has the funniest part in the film, although it could have had a bit more meaning rather then just the actor/rappers being the main attraction (hint hint: Friday). The movie also features an appearance by writer/producer DJ Pooh as a rather stupid (literally) kidnapper.Pointless, but a feel good movie. One to watch if you have time to kill and feel like listening to very stereotyped black language.
summary: Entertaining - Dre And Snoop Make A Comical Pair.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Loaded with rap music artists including lead actors Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg (now Snoop Lion as I write this in 2014), the 2001 movie THE WASH comprises parts of comedy, buddy movie, and caper flick that subtly add up to a plea for community togetherness and individual forgiveness.  As if there is a law against going more than 90 minutes, THE WASH leaves a few matters unresolved (Dre and Snoop have dates over to their apartment when, last we heard, the landlord turned off the water) and seems in a hurry to get to end the movie after the resolution of the crisis at the car wash, where most of the film takes place.  But despite that zigging and zagging, THE WASH moves along briskly on the strength of its many charming performances, especially that of Dr. Dre.Maybe THE WASH writer-director D.J. Pooh does not want to upstage his star actors as he limits the screen time of the very funny character Slim, whom he portrays.  It's one of those stand-out roles where you'll read the closing credits to see the name of the actor who plays him if, like me, you did not know D.J. Pooh on sight.While not hitting you over the head with it, THE WASH centers on a car wash to symbolize how the young people put petty differences and jealousies aside and support one another.
summary: "But we're both black, so I don't wanna lay you flat"
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Wash is a direct-to-DVD film written and directed by DJ Pooh, who co-wrote the popular Friday with Ice Cube. Starring Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg with cameo appearances and bit roles by nearly every major rapper of the time it was made, no one should start watching this movie expecting any kind of masterpiece. In fact, I actually find this film hard to review when I can't tell if anyone was taking this project seriously. There are times when The Wash seems less like a movie than a loose plot-line that gives a bunch of successful rappers the opportunity to hang out.Dr. Dre plays Sean, unemployed and needing to acquire his half of the rent money soon. His best friend and roommate Dee Loc (Snoop Dogg) suggests that Sean applies for a job at The Wash, where Dee Loc works. Sean impresses the owner Mr. Washington (George Wallace) and is hired as an assistant manager, but soon his seniority over Dee Loc puts a strain on their relationship.Xzibit, Ludacris, Kurupt, Tommy Chong, Shaquille O'Neal, Tommy "Tiny" Lister Jr., Eminem, and Pauly Shore all make appearances in this film. Before you read any further, I want you to notice that Pauly Shore makes an appearance in this film. This should give you an idea about the quality of the film, as well as help you to figure out whether you want to see it or not. In casting his film, DJ Pooh seems to have put more effort into getting these guys together than on his script. O'Neal, for example, shows up solely to punch a guy and look directly into the camera, while Shore plays the coveted role of "Man in Trunk." It's true, Tommy Chong is actually really funny in his brief appearance but many of these roles could have been played by a random, no-name extra. Eminem (in an un-credited role) plays Chris, who was recently fired by Mr. Washington and spends the majority of the film making threatening phone calls. This is not the Eminem from 8 Mile and he seems to be taking his role less seriously than the rest...Like he was the only one in on the joke.Snoop Dogg has a kind of natural screen presence that makes him a charming, funny actor to watch and he's amusing here, but he's just playing an angrier version of himself. Not to say Snoop Dogg has demonstrated a remarkable amount of acting range before, just that he's not doing much here. Dr. Dre isn't given much to do, but he's passable and is both likeable and amusing. It's clear that acting isn't one of his strong suits, but I've seen worse performances by non-actors. While following the characters of Sean and Dee Loc, DJ Pooh decided to have radio stations in the background announcing the world premiere of the new song by Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg. When Sean and Dee Loc are listening to songs by Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg it just feels awkward and really jerks you out of the movie. This decision, among others, is why I'm not sure DJ Pooh was even trying to make a coherent movie.If you've seen Friday, you know what type of humor to expect from this film. The jokes revolve around the character's distinct, sometimes stereotypical personalities, ghetto jokes, drug jokes, and the occasional flatulence. Ice Cube's influence on the script for Friday is pretty evident as, despite having a similar sense of humor and a similar tone, Friday was a much better and funnier film than The Wash. Many of the jokes feel forced and there's not much consistency or coherency to the script. It feels like a compilation of loosely-related sketches like you'd see on a ghetto version of In Living Color and even with a 90-minute running time, it can grow tedious. No movie like this would be complete without several clichéd sequences and this movie delivers (the bikini-wash being a glaring one). None of the humor is particularly intelligent or even witty, but I admit that I did laugh out loud during several scenes. The Wash also boasts what may be the most inept, hilarious kidnappers to ever grace the screen, but that's a minor compliment. Going back to the lack of consistency, the ending is a problem; while I never did personally, I'd guess that DJ Pooh intended you to care about the relationship between Sean and Dee Loc and yet the movie ends so abruptly. After the big climax, it just ends...Like DJ Pooh ran out of film, time, or ideas.So is The Wash a waste of time? Not really. As a film, it has better production value than most straight-to-DVD movies. It looks like it had the same budget as Friday. Furthermore, this is a film made for a certain audience and I can't completely criticize a film that I assume wasn't taken seriously by its makers and (I presume) set out to be nothing more than a stoner comedy.  The Wash is a film that you know you will love or hate simply by glancing at the DVD or reading this review. If it looks like the "best movie ever," you will probably enjoy it and it will find frequent rotation in your DVD player while you're hanging out with your friends. If it looks "terrible" and "just as bad as Friday," this is not a movie you want to waste your time on. While I'll never go out of my way to watch this again, I'd happily watch it if a friend put it on. It's nothing special or impressive, but it has its moments.GRADE: C
summary: Nothing Special, But Not Without Its Moments

reviewText: IN THIS MOVIE, SEAN [DR. DRE] GETS A JOB AT A CAR WASH, BUT WHEN HE BECOMES THE ASSISTANT MANAGER AT THE WASH, PROBLEMS BEGIN TO PLAGUE HIS FRIENDSHIP WITH DEE LOC [SNOOP DOGG]. IT'S BASICALLY A BUNCH OF RAPPERS AND OUT OF WORK ACTORS TRYIN TO MAKE A MOVIE, WITH TERRIBLE RESULTS. THIS MOVIE HAS CAMEOS BY SHAQUILLE O NEAL, PAULY SHORE, LUDACRIS, EMINEM, AND DJ POOH. reviewText: I LOVE this movie, don't get me wrong.  Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg/Lion, DJ Pooh, even George Wallace!?  What a cast.  When I saw this in the theater I couldn't wait to own a copy of this movie.  After buying the original release when it first came out I was expecting the same quality when I repurchased this item from Amazon to replace the one I lost.  I don't know who's fault this is but the overall quality of the movie is subpar in my opinion.  There are parts of the movie where the image gets so grainy that it resembles some bad bootleg copies I've ... heard about.  Even the sound fluctuates from time to time.  The disc was delivered loose in the case itself so the underside was scratched to hell and had a visible ring of wear on it.  I doubted it would even play.  To it's credit it played more than once (I watched it repeatedly to be sure) without any skipping or anything so I couldn't return it.  Then again, it was only $5 bucks.  I say it's A WASH.
summary: Is this a bootleg back alley copy???

reviewText: The Wash starring Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg, George Wallace, D.J. Pooh, Bruce Bruce (Comic View), Ludacris, Eminem and a special appearance by Shaq will have you laughing and hanging on to the edge of your seat.  I bypassed this movie when it hit theaters because the previews deceived me.  However, I am thrilled that I did view it once it went to video.Sean (Dr. Dre) and Dee Loc (Snoop Dogg) are two roommates that are late paying their rent.  The landlord cuts the water off for non-payment of rent at a very critically funny moment.  Dee Loc encourages Sean to get a job at the local Car Wash with him. The Wash has some colorful employees, funny antics happening all day, shady type customers and a boss named Mr. Washington (George Wallace) that come together to make a comedy worth seeing.  It reminds me of the 1970s flick entitled CarWash.The movie really hooks the viewer once Mr. Washington hires Sean as Dee Loc's supervisor instead of as his peer/co-worker.  The tension flares up and the comedy really erupts.  Once it appears that the friendship is ruined, their boss is kidnapped by what appears to be the mob or gangsters.  The two roommates come together to try and rescue their boss.  The rescue attempt will have the viewer in stitches and likely telling friends about the comedy for days to come.

reviewText: This film was all washed up!!!  I know it was a comedy and I did not have high expectations, but I only laughed during a few scenes.  The one when Sean was sitting on the toilet after eating a bad burrito, and the scene when DJ Pooh's character was being a bumbling criminal.  Oh yeah then there was the scene where all Shaq's character did was speak with his fist, and sent C-Money flying in the air.Aside of that this movie was just dumb.  Dee Loc and Sean are friends that seem to spend more time arguing, and trying to party and they are one step from eviction.  Dre loses his job at the footlocker, and is trying to figure out where he will get his next gig.  He ends up getting a job at The Wash, meets the woman of his dreams, and Dee Loc keeps trying to mess up with Sean trying to fix up the mess.  Sean is the more responsible of the two, while Dee Loc is always trying to get over, or get his hustle on.  Due to non payment of rent, the landlord decides to cut the water off in their apartment.  The Wash is a car wash, and seems everyone who works there is working hard not to work, spending time watching BET on TV or stealing the lose money left in the customers cars.  Sean lies to a woman he meets at the Wash about what he does, but eventually the truth does come out.Mr. Washington is kidnapped, Dee and Sean find a way to save him.  Mr. Washington is also having to deal with a disgruntled employee (Eminem) who spends the majority of the movie calling him and yelling into the phone like a nut case.  What really ticked me off was the way the movie just suddenly ended.  It left you going......is that it?There was one scene that pretty much shows me how Ghetto and the lack of respect some women have for themselves and will settle for any type of behavior.I just remembered on other scene that did make me chuckle a little.  One of the car wash guys is trying to use a customer's cell phone and it's the voice activated kind.  Instead of saying Four, he is saying foe and the voice on the phone says "Again fool."The film was stupid, senseless and moderately funny.  If you are expecting this film to be anything near what Friday was you will be very disappointed.  I love comedies, but this one left me dry.Lamont Bently (Moesha), Bruce Bruce, DJ Pooh, Kurupt, Xzibit, Truth Hurts, Tiny Lister (Friday, The Fifth Element), Angell Conwell (Soul Plane), Pierre(For Da Love of Money), Pauly Shore, Eminem have parts in the film.  One more thing.  I can't forget about Dee Locs dream sequence, translation some quick T&A; for those that like that kind of thing.  I've seen the movie, I won't see it again, and this movie will never be a part of my DVD collection.
summary: This comedy is all Washed up!!!
